--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
> Sven Gorts wrote:
> 
---8><---
> > 
> > Personally I prefer using the message string to
> > document the assertion rather than defining the
> > error message upon failure. To me doing so seems
> > logical because JUnit reports assertion failures.
> > 
> > So instead of the style proposed above I'd prefer:
> > 
> >   assertTrue("someBoolean is true", someBoolean);
> > 
> >   assertEquals("The answer is right",
> >     expected,
> >     actual);
> > 
> >   assertNotNull("Joe has a name", joe.getName());
> > 
> > The reason why I prefer using this style is
> because
> > I find assertions like the one below confusing to
> read
> > 
> >   assertTrue("someBoolean is not true!",
> someBoolean);
> 
> Strange... I don't want a failure message to tell me
> something that 
> isn't true. I believe a failure message should say
> "This expected result 
> isn't right/didn't happen," rather than simply
> writing the assertion as 
> text. (I can read the code.)

Well that's a good point, at least from the side of
the failure messages. However reading the code I often
got confused by reading the messages rather than the
code. 

> Your failure messages look like comments to me.
>

Exactly. I use the messages to document the assertion.
When a failure occurs I get something like:

junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Joe has a name
	at SomeTest.test(SomeTest.java:10)

Which I read as: 
  The assertion stating that Joe has a name failed 

Kind regards,
